title: Eye gaze mapping
code: ggplot(data= EyegazeData, aes(x= x, y= y, color= target, fill= target)) +   geom_point(data= EyegazeData %>% group_by(target, target_x, target_y) %>% summarise(.groups="drop"),              aes(x= target_x, y= target_y), shape= 21, size= 10, fill= 'white') +    geom_point(alpha= 0.5, shape= 21, show.legend=FALSE) +    ggtitle('Raw eye gaze')

what: Using lm2 to transform the eye gaze
title: Eye gaze mapping
code: lm2aff <- fit_transformation(target_x + target_y ~ x + y,  EyegazeData, transformation = 'affine') #>  #> SAMPLING FOR MODEL 'tridim_transformation' NOW (CHAIN 1). #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1: Gradient evaluation took 0.001 seconds #> Chain 1: 1000 transitions using 10 leapfrog steps per transition would take 10 seconds. #> Chain 1: Adjust your expectations accordingly! #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1: Iteration:    1 / 2000 [  0%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  200 / 2000 [ 10%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  400 / 2000 [ 20%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  600 / 2000 [ 30%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration:  800 / 2000 [ 40%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 1000 / 2000 [ 50%]  (Warmup) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 1001 / 2000 [ 50%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 1200 / 2000 [ 60%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 1400 / 2000 [ 70%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 1600 / 2000 [ 80%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 1800 / 2000 [ 90%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1: Iteration: 2000 / 2000 [100%]  (Sampling) #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1:  Elapsed Time: 4.281 seconds (Warm-up) #> Chain 1:                3.095 seconds (Sampling) #> Chain 1:                7.376 seconds (Total) #> Chain 1: adjusted_gaze <- predict(lm2aff, summary=TRUE, probs=NULL) colnames(adjusted_gaze) <- c('adjX', 'adjY') adjusted_gaze <- cbind(EyegazeData, adjusted_gaze)   ggplot(data= adjusted_gaze, aes(x= adjX, y= adjY, color= target, fill= target)) +   geom_point(data= adjusted_gaze %>% group_by(target, target_x, target_y) %>% summarise(.groups="drop"),              aes(x= target_x, y= target_y), shape= 21, size= 10, fill= 'white') +    geom_point(alpha= 0.5, shape = 21, show.legend = FALSE) +    xlab('x')+   ylab('y')+   ggtitle('Adjusted eye gaze')

title: Transformation matrices
text: Number parameters: 2 translation: \(a_1\), \(a_2\) \[ \begin{bmatrix}  1 & 0 & a_1 \\  0 & 1 & a_2 \\  0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \]

title: Transformation matrices
text: Number parameters: 4 translation: \(a_1\), \(a_2\) scaling: \(\phi\) rotation: \(\theta\) \[ \begin{bmatrix}  b_1 & b_2 & a_1 \\ -b_2 & b_1 & a_2 \\  0   & 0   & 1 \end{bmatrix} \] Euclidean transformation special case, can compute rotation (\(\theta\)) single scaling (\(\phi\)) coefficients, follows: \[ \phi = \sqrt{b_1^2 + b_2^2}\\ \theta = tan^{-1}(\frac{b_2}{b_1}) \]

title: Transformation matrices
text: Number parameters: 6 translation: \(a_1\), \(a_2\) scaling · rotation · sheer: \(b_1\), \(b_2\), \(b_3\), \(b_4\) \[ \begin{bmatrix}  b_1 & b_2 & a_1 \\  b_3 & b_4 & a_2 \\  0   & 0   & 1 \end{bmatrix} \]

title: Transformation matrices
text: Number parameters: 8 translation: \(a_1\), \(a_2\) scaling · rotation · sheer · projection: \(b_1\)…\(b_6\) \[ \begin{bmatrix}  b_1 & b_2 & a_1 \\  b_3 & b_4 & a_2 \\  b_5 & b_6 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \]

title: Transformation matrices
text: Number parameters: 3 translation: \(a_1\), \(a_2\), \(a_3\) \[ \begin{bmatrix}  1 & 0 & 0 & a_1 \\  0 & 1 & 0 & a_2 \\  0 & 0 & 1 & a_3 \\  0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \]

title: Transformation matrices
text: Number parameters: 5 translation: \(a_1\), \(a_2\), \(a_3\) scaling: \(\phi\) rotation: \(\theta\) Euclidean rotations, opted use coefficient \(b_3\) code scaling (\(\phi\)), whereas \(b_2 = sin(\theta)\) \(b_1=\phi~ cos(\theta)\). coefficients computed follows: \[ \phi = \sqrt{b_1^2 + b_2^2}\\ \theta = tan^{-1}(\frac{b_2}{b_1}) \]

title: Transformation matrices
text: Note fitting \(\phi\) computed \(b_1\) \(b_2\) fly. \[ \begin{bmatrix}  \phi & 0   & 0   & a_1 \\  0    & b_1 &-b_2 & a_2 \\  0    & b_2 & b_1 & a_3 \\  0    & 0   & 0   & 1 \end{bmatrix} \]

title: Transformation matrices
text: Number parameters: 12 translation: \(a_1\), \(a_2\), \(a_3\) scaling · rotation · sheer: \(b_1\)…\(b_9\) \[ \begin{bmatrix}  b_1 & b_2 & b_3 & a_1 \\  b_4 & b_5 & b_6 & a_2 \\  b_7 & b_8 & b_9 & a_3 \\  0   & 0   &  0   & 1 \end{bmatrix} \]

title: Transformation matrices
text: Number parameters: 15 translation: \(a_1\), \(a_2\), \(a_3\) scaling · rotation · sheer · projection: \(b_1\)…\(b_12\) \[ \begin{bmatrix}  b_1    & b_2    & b_3    & a_1 \\  b_4    & b_5    & b_6    & a_2 \\  b_7    & b_8    & b_9    & a_3 \\  b_{10} & b_{11} & b_{12} & 1 \end{bmatrix} \]

title: Bayesian Statistics for 2D/3D Transformations
text: can call main function either via formula specifies dependent independent variables data table supplying two tables one containing independent variables one containing dependent variables. former call whereas latter See also vignette("calibration", package="TriDimRegression") example using TriDimRegression 2D eye gaze data vignette("comparing_faces", package="TriDimRegression") example working 3D facial landmarks data. 2D data, can fit "translation" (2 parameters translation ), "euclidean" (4 parameters: 2 translation, 1 scaling, 1 rotation), "affine" (6 parameters: 2 translation 4 jointly describe scaling, rotation sheer), "projective" (8 parameters: affine plus 2 additional parameters account projection). 3D data, can fit "translation" (3 translation ), "euclidean_x", "euclidean_y", "euclidean_z" (5 parameters: 3 translation scale, 1 rotation, 1 scaling), "affine" (12 parameters: 3 translation 9 account scaling, rotation, sheer), "projective" (15 parameters: affine plus 3 additional parameters account projection). transformations. details matrices constructed, see vignette("transformation_matrices", package="TriDimRegression"). data fitted, can extract transformation coefficients via coef() function matrix via transformation_matrix(). Predicted data, either based original data new data, can generated via predict(). Bayesian R-squared can computed without adjustment via R2() function. three cases, choice summary (mean + specified quantiles) full posterior samples. loo() waic() provide corresponding measures can used comparison via loo::loo_compare() function.

what: Fitting Bidimensional or Tridimensional Regression / Geometric Transformation Models via Formula. — fit_transformation
title: Fitting Bidimensional or Tridimensional Regression / Geometric Transformation Models via Formula. — fit_transformation
text: Fits Bidimensional Tridimensional regression / geometric transformation models using Stan engine. formula described dependent independent numeric variables data. See also fit_transformation_df. 2D data, can fit "translation" (2 parameters translation ), "euclidean" (4 parameters: 2 translation, 1 scaling, 1 rotation), "affine" (6 parameters: 2 translation 4 jointly describe scaling, rotation sheer), "projective" (8 parameters: affine plus 2 additional parameters account projection). 3D data, can fit "translation" (3 translation ), "euclidean_x", "euclidean_y", "euclidean_z" (5 parameters: 3 translation scale, 1 rotation, 1 scaling), "affine" (12 parameters: 3 translation 9 account scaling, rotation, sheer), "projective" (15 parameters: affine plus 3 additional parameters account projection). transformations. details transformation matrices computation scale rotation parameters please see vignette("transformation_matrices", package = "TriDimRegression")

title: Fitting Bidimensional or Tridimensional Regression / Geometric Transformation Models via Formula. — fit_transformation
code: # S3 method for formula fit_transformation(   formula,   data,   transformation,   priors = NULL,   chains = 1,   cores = NULL,   ... )

title: Fitting Bidimensional or Tridimensional Regression / Geometric Transformation Models via Formula. — fit_transformation
text: formula symbolic description model fitted format Xdep + Ydep ~ Xind + Yind, Xdep Ydep dependent Xind Yind independent variables data data frame containing variables model. transformation transformation used: "translation" (2D 3D), "euclidean" (2D), "euclidean_x", "euclidean_y", "euclidean_z" (3D, rotation , respectively, x, y, z axis), "affine" (2D 3D), "projective" (2D 3D). priors named list parameters prior distributions parameters (translation, normal distribution), b (parameters, normal distribution), sigma (residual variance, exponential). E.g., list("" = c(0, 10), "b"= c(0, 1), "sigma"=1). Default priors "" = c(0, max_absolute_difference_in_means(d, iv)) / 2), "b" = c(0, max_absolute_difference_in_means(d, iv)) / 2), "sigma" = 1 * sd(dv). chains Number chains sampling. cores Number CPU cores use sampling. omitted, available cores used. ... Additional arguments passed sampling function.

what: Fitting Bidimensional or Tridimensional Regression / Geometric Transformation Models via Two Tables. — fit_transformation_df
title: Fitting Bidimensional or Tridimensional Regression / Geometric Transformation Models via Two Tables. — fit_transformation_df
text: Fits Bidimensional Tridimensional regression / geometric transformation models using Stan engine. Two sets coordinates supplied via iv (independent variable) dv (dependent one). two tables must dimensions (N×2 N×3). 2D data, can fit "translation" (2 translation ), "euclidean" (4 parameters: 2 translation, 1 scaling, 1 rotation), "affine" (6 parameters: 2 translation 4 jointly describe scaling, rotation sheer), "projective" (8 parameters: affine plus 2 additional parameters account projection). 3D data, can fit "translation" (3 translation ), "euclidean_x", "euclidean_y", "euclidean_z" (5 parameters: 3 translation scale, 1 rotation, 1 scaling), "affine" (12 parameters: 3 translation 9 account scaling, rotation, sheer), "projective" (15 parameters: affine plus 3 additional parameters account projection). transformations. details transformation matrices computation scale rotation parameters please see vignette("transformation_matrices", package = "TriDimRegression")

title: Fitting Bidimensional or Tridimensional Regression / Geometric Transformation Models via Two Tables. — fit_transformation_df
code: fit_transformation_df(   iv,   dv,   transformation,   priors = NULL,   chains = 1,   cores = NULL,   ... )

title: Fitting Bidimensional or Tridimensional Regression / Geometric Transformation Models via Two Tables. — fit_transformation_df
text: iv data frame containing independent variable, must numeric , N×2 N×3. dv data frame containing dependent variable, must numeric , N×2 N×3. transformation transformation used: "translation" (2D 3D), "euclidean" (2D), "euclidean_x", "euclidean_y", "euclidean_z" (3D, rotation , respectively, x, y, z axis), "affine" (2D 3D), "projective" (2D 3D). priors named list parameters prior distributions parameters (translation, normal distribution), b (parameters, normal distribution), sigma (residual variance, exponential). E.g., list("" = c(0, 10), "b"= c(0, 1), "sigma"=1). Default priors "" = c(0, max_absolute_difference_in_means(d, iv)) / 2), "b" = c(0, max_absolute_difference_in_means(d, iv)) / 2), "sigma" = 1 * sd(dv). chains Number chains sampling. cores Number CPU cores use sampling. omitted, available cores used. ... Additional arguments passed sampling function.

title: The 'TriDimRegression' package. — TriDimRegression-package
text: Fits 2D 3D geometric transformations. Provides posterior via Stan. Includes computation LOO WAIC information criteria, R-squared. fit transformation, call main function either via formula specifies dependent independent variables data table supplying two tables one containing independent variables one containing dependent variables. 2D data, can fit "translation" (2 parameters translation ), "euclidean" (4 parameters: 2 translation, 1 scaling, 1 rotation), "affine" (6 parameters: 2 translation 4 jointly describe scaling, rotation sheer), "projective" (8 parameters: affine plus 2 additional parameters account projection). 3D data, can fit "translation" (3 translation ), "euclidean_x", "euclidean_y", "euclidean_z" (5 parameters: 3 translation scale, 1 rotation, 1 scaling), "affine" (12 parameters: 3 translation 9 account scaling, rotation, sheer), "projective" (15 parameters: affine plus 3 additional parameters account projection). transformations. details transformation matrices computation scale rotation parameters please see vignette("transformation_matrices", package = "TriDimRegression") data fitted, can extract transformation coefficients via coef function matrix via  transformation_matrix. Predicted data, either based original data new data, can generated via  predict. Bayesian R-squared can computed without adjustment via R2 function. three cases, choice summary (mean + specified quantiles) full posterior samples.  loo  waic provide corresponding measures can used comparison via loo::loo_compare() function.
